column19: Total effect by type of program

column15: We try to, in detail, estimate the total effects (through time) for the individual recipient of SM's core program and then extrapolate the efficacy based on the ratio of efficacy based on the ratio of pre-post changes of those reached (not treated! Which would give different results) from SM's recent data. The cost effectiveness of the different programs relies on the assumption that this ratio represents the true differences in the efficacy of the program. We do not currently incorporate broader frames fo evidence into our estimation of other programs like we do for the core program. E.g., we do not consider the broader evidence of tele-therapy's efficacy when estimating the efficacy of SM's tele-therapy program. We simply assume we've done a decent job at estimating the effectiveness of the core program, and that it appears that SM's tele-therapy is ~90% as effective as that.

column12: This is the predicted effect for the average intervention delivered to groups or by lay persons from our review of psychotherapy in LMICs.
This is the predicted effect of a study that appears similar to Strong Minds.I don't give it more weight because this prediction is very imprecise (there are not many studies for some variables).
Seems unusually high effects at 6 months and also high decay. Should wait and see if non-preliminary results are as dramatic.

column3: Bolton et al 2003 (assuming same programme as core SM)
column12: Credence was 0.3 in the decay, think I will update to be less because the intervention doesn't clearly end. Groups continue to meet, so the intervention hasn't really ended at the 6 month follow-up (Bass et al., 2006). If Strong Minds groups continue still to operate like this, then this is a feature not a bug and I should consider increasing the weight given.

column1: Assign low weight , maybe less or same as 2007
column12: I give this study a weight of 10%, because while its control group wasn't randomly assigned the control group was similar on observable characteristics. I don't give it more weight because I assume it overestimates the effect for two reasons: I assume the refusers are less likely to improve due and that being in the control group was worse than not getting any help at all.
I don't give this much weight because Bolton et al., (2008) has a very small sample size, treats a different population than what SM targets and is very unclear on many details of its implementation.

column3: SM 2019-2020 pre-post data (shown in tables below!)
column12: I'm not sure whether I should use this at all. Pre-post decay rate assumes that control group, if it existed would improve 0% compared to baseline. That is unlikely if individuals are selected for unusually high levels of depression (regression to the mean). I think it's better to treat as an upper bound.
